bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, May 26, 1956

div1.p: Ames mentions Lambert's devotion to her husband and would like to see Proposition 1 and Proposition 4 passed.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, May 26, 1956
div1.opener:
JESSIE DANIEL AMES
THE WREN'S NEST
TRYON, N. C.
26 May, 1956
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I returned to Tryon late yesterday evening after a two weeks' absence
from the state. So the information which you asked for, and which I
am sending you, may be too late for your purposes. Naturally, I re-
gret this delay.

I agree with you that Mr. Lambert is greatly distressed by the turn
of events which makes it seem that he might have been instrumental
in the exclusion of my husband's name from the “Lambert” bill. The
one thing that has kept the frail old man alive has been his faith
that “justice will prevail” if he continued the campaign. His loy-
alty to my husband has always touched me deeply.

My limited service in getting bills through legislative bodies leads
me to believe that an amendment to an already passed bill by one
house stands a better chance of final passage than does a new bill.

The two men in the Yellow Fever experiment in Cuba for whom my hus-
band had the greatest admirationwere Major Reed and Captain Lazear.
Major Reed has been adequately meorialized, I believe. I do agree
with you that something should me done to bring the name of Captain
Lazear prominently before the public, or before the medical profess-
ion. I would like Proposition 1 passed for this reason.

On the other hand, I am for any one of the four which can be passed
by the Congress. I want Mr. Lambert to die in the knowledge that
his services have been recognized and that his faith has been justified.
I wish that Proposition 4 could be passed. Mr. Lambert has worked
for this particular recognition, and as the years have passed and
he has grownold and feeble and nearly blind, he could have built up
a greater conception of the value of his services all out of pro-
potion to your evaluation of them.

I know that I have done this in relation to my husband's record. That
is, out of proportion to the value which Major Kean, General Ireland,
General Truby and others attributed to his record. I would like this
recognition only in part for myself. For the most part, I want it for
my children, two of whom are doctors, and for my grandson to whom
my son has talked about his grandfather's work in “ wiping out the
scourge of yellow fever.” But then you know how much I do want this
official recognition.

I shall write to Senators Ervin and Scott and Congressman Jones as
soon as I know the number of the bill and its status in the Senate.
In committee, pigeon holed or under consideration? I take it that
it is not pigeoholed.

I like hearing from you again. You never sent me the pictures you
took at Quemados in 1952. You wrote that you would.
div1.closer: Cordially yours Jessie Daniel Ames (Mrs. Roger Post Ames)
